summary: This document is an email chain from June 2020 discussing press inquiries about a reported U.S. Department of Justice Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request to the United Kingdom to interview Prince Andrew regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. It shows internal DOJ coordination on a sensitive and confidential matter and the standard policy of not commenting on such communications.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: British media reports that the DOJ made an MLAT request to the UK to force him to answer questions in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Kadhim Shubber
persons.context: Journalist who sent the initial press query to the DOJ about the reported MLAT request concerning Prince Andrew.

connections.description: The press query references an investigation into Prince Andrew's links to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: DOJ MLAT Request to UK
events.description: The U.S. Department of Justice reportedly issued a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty request to the United Kingdom regarding Prince Andrew to force him to answer questions in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Press Inquiries on MLAT
events.description: British media reports on the MLAT request generate numerous press inquiries to the DOJ Office of Public Affairs.

keyFacts: A U.S. Department of Justice Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request was reportedly made to the United Kingdom regarding Prince Andrew in connection with the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.
The MLAT request is described as 'highly sensitive, and confidential' by a DOJ official in the email chain.

The DOJ's standard policy, as referenced in the emails, is not to publicly comment on communications with foreign governments on investigative matters, including confirming or denying their existence.
The initial press query came from Kadhim Shubber, a reporter for the Financial Times, referencing an article from The Sun.
The email chain shows internal DOJ coordination between the Office of Public Affairs (OPA) and the Criminal Division (CRM) regarding the handling of these sensitive press inquiries.
